messages.content: Offshore bettors are predicting that Democratic nominee Kamala Harris will defeat Republican nominee Donald Trump in the 2024 presidential election. The odds on Polymarket, a crypto-trading platform, have shifted significantly since July 21, when Joe Biden withdrew from the race. As of Monday evening, Harris is favored with a 52% chance of winning, while Trump’s chances stand at 46%. This shift follows Harris and her running mate, Tim Walz, concluding a four-day tour of five battleground states. Betting, which is not legal in the U.S., has been accurate in predicting past presidential elections.

Campaign officials for Vice President Kamala Harris have announced they may debate Republican nominee Donald Trump in Grand Rapids, Michigan, on Sept. 25. However, no agreement has been reached yet between Trump, NBC, and Harris’s team regarding this debate. The only confirmed debate so far is scheduled for Sept. 10 in Philadelphia, which could set the stage for a potential showdown in Grand Rapids. If the debate takes place, it would bring Trump back to Michigan, a critical swing state where he last rallied supporters.

Central Valley farmers express that Donald Trump’s policies align more with their water needs compared to Kamala Harris’s. Tom Barcellos, a lifelong farmer and president of the Lower Tule River Irrigation District, supports Republican policies and voices his frustration with the Democratic super-majority in both Sacramento and the federal government. The federal government controls a major water delivery system that supplies agricultural water to the San Joaquin Valley, where many farmers have grown frustrated with drought conditions and policies protecting endangered fish. Despite Harris’s time as a U.S. senator and California’s attorney general, she has not been significantly linked to water issues, according to both farmers and environmental advocates.

Bernie Sanders has warned that Donald Trump might attempt to deny the results of the 2024 election if he loses. Sanders’s concern follows Trump’s false claims that Harris has been using artificial intelligence to create fake images of thousands of attendees at her rallies, even going as far as to state that “nobody” showed up at a recent event in Detroit. Sanders accused Trump of laying the groundwork to convince his supporters that election results in key states like Pennsylvania and Michigan are fraudulent. He warned that if Trump could convince his base that thousands of rally-goers didn’t exist, he could do the same with election returns. Despite efforts from Trump’s allies to focus on Harris’s progressive stances during her 2020 primary run and her record in the Biden administration, these attempts have been largely unsuccessful.

Recent polls show Kamala Harris leading Donald Trump by three percentage points, according to a Morning Consult survey. The poll has Harris at 47% and Trump at 44%, marking the fourth consecutive week where Harris has held the lead. With third-party candidates, including Robert F. Kennedy Jr., on the ballot, Harris’s lead increases by two points. Harris’s lead is also growing in YouGov/Economist surveys, and a Reuters/Ipsos poll shows her leading Trump by one point when voters can express uncertainty about their choice. A New York Times/Siena poll found that 64% of voters are now paying closer attention to the race following the June 27 Biden-Trump debate. However, questions remain about the impact of Harris’s gender and race on voters, with 32% of Americans viewing these factors as either helpful or harmful, compared to 24% who see them as positive.

A new poll indicates that Donald Trump is at risk of losing Florida in the upcoming election. The survey, conducted by USA TODAY, Suffolk University, and WSVN-TV, suggests that Trump’s lead in Florida is only five percentage points ahead of Kamala Harris’s 42%, which is smaller than previous polls since July 10. The poll’s margin of error is 4.4%, putting Florida’s outcome in question. Despite Florida’s recent Republican lean, underscored by Governor Ron DeSantis’s landslide win, this poll suggests the state may not be an easy victory for Trump.

CNN analyst Harry Enten has warned that, historically, Donald Trump has been underestimated in the polls, despite Harris gaining momentum in key swing states. Enten noted that both in 2016 and 2020, Trump outperformed poll predictions by five points. While Harris currently holds a four-point advantage in key swing states, Enten cautioned that similar polling errors could allow Trump to win. Even though there are challenges, polling data among registered voters who are certain they will vote has remained steady since Harris became the nominee.

Elon Musk, the owner of X (formerly known as Twitter), has invited Kamala Harris for an interview on his platform after a two-hour conversation with Donald Trump on Spaces. Musk extended the same invitation to Harris, who has not given any media interviews since announcing her candidacy. Harris is scheduled to participate in three presidential debates against Trump, though her campaign team criticized Musk's platform for technical difficulties that delayed Trump’s interview by 40 minutes.

Former President Donald Trump, in an interview with Breitbart News, criticized Kamala Harris for agreeing to only one interview with ABC’s George Stephanopoulos. Trump compared the situation to outgoing President Joe Biden, accusing Harris of avoiding tough interviews. Trump himself has agreed to three other debates, while Harris has only confirmed one.

As Harris gains popularity and prepares for the election, Trump has increasingly focused on the size of his rally crowds and his claims of widespread enthusiasm among Democrats. Despite efforts by Republicans to shift focus to the campaign, Trump has remained preoccupied with President Biden’s departure from the race and his potential legal troubles. Trump has been accused of inflating his rally attendance numbers, even claiming that one event rivaled Martin Luther King Jr.’s 1963 “I Have a Dream” speech.

In a conversation with Elon Musk, Donald Trump accused Kamala Harris of supporting far-left policies, including putting tampons in boys’ bathrooms. He pointed to her choice of Tim Walz as a running mate as evidence of her radicalism, claiming Harris supports open borders, defunding the police, and ending fracking. Musk disagreed, asserting that Trump’s comments were an attempt to cast Harris as far-left when she is more moderate. Trump likened Harris to Bernie Sanders, predicting that a Democrat would win without warning.

Both campaigns are ramping up efforts in Georgia. The Trump campaign has invested more in advertising in Georgia than anywhere else in the country. Meanwhile, Harris’s campaign is targeting low-propensity Democratic voters, including seniors. At a Harris campaign event in southwest Atlanta, Georgia State Senator Nan Orrock joined other Democrats in urging voters to get to the polls. Pennsylvania Congresswoman Chrissy Houlahan also visited Atlanta to discuss voter turnout. Tommy Pigott, the RNC’s Strategic Communications Director, emphasized the importance of the ground game in Georgia, where more rallies and visits from Harris are expected in the coming months.
